title: 113_hr995
content:
The Act is titled the "Organ Mountains National Monument Establishment Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled "Organ Mountains National Monument Establishment Act" defines key terms such as City, County, Management plan, Map, Monument, Secretary, State director, and State. SEC. 3. WATER RIGHTS.

This Act does not reserve any water rights for the United States within the monument and does not affect existing water rights, including those held by the United States.

SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF MONUMENT.

The Organ Mountains monument is established in the State, consisting of approximately 54,800 acres of public land in Dona Ana County as depicted on the map.

SEC. 5. PURPOSES. The monument aims to conserve and protect various resources for the benefit of present and future generations. The Secretary manages the monument to conserve, protect, and enhance resources in accordance with relevant laws. Only uses that further the monument's purposes are allowed, with restrictions on motorized vehicle use to designated roads. The management plan allows for the use of motorized vehicles and mechanical equipment for specific purposes. No new roads can be built in the monument unless deemed necessary for public safety or natural resource protection. Grazing leases and permits are issued in accordance with existing laws, and utility right-of-ways are not restricted. The management plan allows for the use of motorized vehicles and mechanical equipment for specific purposes. No new roads can be built in the monument unless necessary for public safety or natural resource protection. The Secretary can authorize, renew, or upgrade utility right-of-ways through the monument in a way that minimizes harm, following relevant laws and conditions. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the monument within 3 years of the Act's enactment, in consultation with State, tribal, and local governments, the public, and interested Federal agencies. The Secretary must file the map and legal description of the monument soon after the Act's enactment, with corrections allowed. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection in specific offices. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife is not affected by this Act. The State retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on public land within the monument. No buffer zones are allowed around the monument. All Federal land within the monument is withdrawn, except for valid existing rights. All Federal lands within the United States are withdrawn from various forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under public land laws, as well as from location, entry, and patent under mining laws, and from operation of mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws. The Secretary will allow hunting and trapping in the monument, with limitations such as designated areas and periods where hunting or trapping is not allowed for safety or legal reasons. The Secretary must consult with the State agency before closing any part of the monument to hunting or trapping. Additionally, there is a provision for the release of a wilderness study area. SEC. 10. Release of Wilderness Study Area includes the Organ Mountains, Organ Needles, and Pena Blanca areas from wilderness designation study. SEC. 11. Law enforcement personnel have unrestricted access to the monument. SEC. 12. Establishment of the National Landscape Conservation System. The monument designated by this Act will be part of the National Landscape Conservation System.
